Global energy demand has connected with the environment and economic concern, and this led to an intensive focus toward carbon dioxide (CO2) capture and conversion to valuable products. Chemical conversion of CO2 via hydrogenation to methane is the interesting process that meets these growing needs. The necessity of development of a low price, and active sustainable catalyst resulted in focus on utilization of Ni and SiO2 containing catalysts for CO2 to methane at mild reaction temperature. In this contribution, nickel silicate (NiSil) nanotubes sample was prepared by solvothermal process and different loadings (0.25 to 1.0 wt.%) of Zn nanoparticles were chemically deposited on the surface of NiSil nanotubes. The 0.25Zn-NiSil catalyst exhibited significant high performance with CO2 conversion greater than 90 % at 300 °C with high good stability (for 48 h). The synthesized samples were analyzed using XRD, FT-IR, TEM, DRUV–vis XPS, H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, NH3-TPD and N2 physisorption techniques. The results indicate that the synthesized nickel silicate nanotubes possess high specific surface area and pore volume and deposition of Zn loading on NiSil surface increases reducibility and number of basic sites due to interaction between Zn-NiSil. Highly dispersed Zn-NiSil species on the surface 0.25Zn-NiSil sample are the key factors for high catalytic activity in CO2 methanation. This is a paramount reason for the energy and environmental concerns. Scientists explored different approaches to reduce the continuing increase in CO2 emissions, which includes controlling, capturing, and utilization of CO2 [1,2]. The catalytic conversion of CO2 into CH4 lowers its emission and meets the energy requirements. The exothermic nature of CO2 methanation leads to an increase in temperature of the reaction, which affects adversely CO2 conversion due to the chemical kinetics of reaction [3]. The CO2 conversion is low in accordance with the chemical equilibrium which depends greatly on temperature and pressure. The typical catalysts for CO2 methanation are composed of precious and transition metals dispersed on different metal oxide supports. Metals and metal oxide supports such as Ru [4–6], Rh [7], Pd [8,9], Ni [10–12] and Al2O3 [13], CeO2 [14,15], SiO2 [16], TiO2 [17], and ZrO2 [18] respectively were widely investigated by different research groups. However, Ni supported catalysts are extensively utilized for CO2 methanation due to their inexpensive nature and high catalytic performance. It was previously reported that catalytic support critically influences the adsorption and activation of CO2 during the methanation process [19]. The silicate materials fulfill the required characteristic properties of support material include low-cost, high thermal stability and porous nature. The unique characteristic properties of silicates make them ideal catalytic supports for adsorption and catalytic applications [20]. The morphology of the nanotube material provides a large surface area with enhanced thermal stability [21]. In the catalytic hydrogenation reaction, metallic nickel sites are responsible for the H2 dissociation, and the hydrogenation activity depends on efficiency of Ni sites. To obtain considerable CO2 methanation activity, a support material that is capable of adsorbing and activating CO2 for the reaction. Silicate materials consists of basic sites could accelerate CO2 adsorption and activation due to large surface area and mesoporous material, which lead to increase in number of active sites on the surface. Additionally, a suitable support ensures the dispersion of the nickel active sites, high thermal stability and circumvent the sintering, which is beneficial to the progress of the catalytic process. The strong interaction between Ni and SiO2 significantly increases selectivity and stability and exhibits outstanding performance for CO2 hydrogenation [22,23]. Nickel silicate nanotubes with layer structure possess unique characteristics and were extensively investigated for different types of applications such as electronic batteries technology and catalysis [21,24]. In addition, Liao et al. [25] used nickel silicate catalysts with high Ni loadings for CO2 methanation and the authors observed that catalyst with a high Ni loading (34.3 wt.%) offered 80 % CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity of 100% at 330 °C although the high Ni loading results low dispersion. The utilization of support and promoters is aimed to reduce the particle agglomeration and improve the stability and catalytic activity in CO2 methanation reaction [26]. Second metals such as Fe, Co, Zr, La and Cu were utilized to modify Ni/Al2O3 supported catalysts, which could improve different characteristics such as metal dispersion, basic sites and CO2 adsorption ability, reducibility, and deactivation resistance [27]. In another report, Liang et al. used lanthanides (La and Ce), alkaline and alkaline earth metals such as Na, K, Mg, and Ca to promote the CO2 methanation performance of the catalyst [28]. Transition metal oxides were also used as catalytically active material in the methanation reaction [1]. The ZnO nanoparticles (NPs) exhibited efficient performance in CO2 capturing process, hence, ZnO NPS were used in photocatalysis to enhance the reduction of CO2. Furthermore, it was reported that the transition metal species such as Cu and Zn could promote the Ga-catalysts in converting CO2 into methanol [29]. Also, researchers demonstrated that the Zn addition of Ni/SiO2 catalysts to stabilize the methane decomposition reaction [30]. Alekseeva et al. [31] observed improvement in catalytic activity of Ni/SiO2 after Zn addition in dehydrogenation of methylcyclohexane reaction. Very recently, Chen et al. optimized the composition of Zn and Ni/SiO2 catalyst for CO2 methanation and the authors observed CO2 conversion higher than 80% at 300 °C, which was due to increase the metal dispersion and H2 adsorption [32]. The solvothermal method is a cost-effective, controlled technique which produce thermally stable nanosized materials with high surface area, excellent dispersion [33]. In addition, utilization of ultrasonication is simple, rapid, and environmentally friendly technique to obtain nanomaterials in high yields at mild operation condition [34]. It is previously reported that metallic nickel sites could efficiently catalyze CO2 methanation, but one of the major drawbacks is the lack of selectivity, linked to side-reactions. The product selectivity can be tuned upon the introduction of support and second metal in combination with Ni. The characteristic of nickel sites, support, and promoting metal work together to provide an enhanced catalytic functionality in the Sabatier reaction [35]. In this contribution, nickel silicate nanotubes samples were synthesized by solvothermal method and then different amounts (0.25–1.0 wt.%) of Zn species were deposited on the surface of nickel silicate nanotubes. Further, we utilized the synthesized catalysts for CO2 methanation reaction to obtain methane at low reaction temperatures. The physicochemical properties of bare and Zn decorated nickel silicate nanotubes samples were investigated by XRD, TEM, FT-IR, DRUV-vis, H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, NH3-TPD and N2 adsorption techniques to correlate the unique characteristics of Zn decorated nickel silicate catalysts with their CO2 methanation activity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The analytical grade reagents of Ni (NO3)2·6H2O, NaOH, Na2SiO3 and Zn (CH3CO2)2·2H2O were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, UK and used as received, without any purification. High purity (99.9 %) CO2, H2, N2 and He gases were obtained from Abdullah Hashim Company, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia. 2.2 Synthesis of nickel silicate nanotubes In a typical synthesis, 2.9 g of Ni (NO3)2·6H2O taken in a glass beaker and dissolved in 30 mL of water and ethanol (50/50 vol ratio) mixed solvent. Then, the calculated amount of Na2SiO3 also dissolved in water and the previously prepared nickel nitrate solution was slowly added under stirring (Scheme 1 ). The stirring was continued for 20 min before adding 0.08 g of NaOH pellets to maintain the pH of the solution around 10. Then, the total contents were transferred into a Teflon lined autoclave to subject solvothermal treatment at 180 °C for 48 h. After the treatment, the powder was obtained after being centrifuged and washed several times with distilled water. Then, it was dried in an electric oven at 80 °C for 4 h. The obtained substance was grounded using mortar and pestle then thermally treated at 450 °C for 4 h. 2.3 Deposition of Zn species over nickel silicate nanotubes A calculated amount of zinc acetate dihydrate (corresponding to weight percent of Zn, between 0.25 and 1.0) was dissolved in 20 mL of deionized water. To this, 5 mL of trisodium citrate solution was added under stirring and continued for an hour. Then, calculated amount of nickel silicate nanotubes powder was added to solution and the total contents were sonicated for 30 min. Then, the material was collected by centrifugation and was washed with water. Then, the powder was dried in oven at 80 °C for 4 h to obtain the final catalyst. 2.4 Characterization of samples The powder XRD patterns of the samples were obtained using Bruker D8Advance powder diffractometer with CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) operated at 40 kV and 200 mA. The wide-angle scanning was performed in the range of 2θ = 10–80° The average crystallite sizes of crystalline phases presented in the samples were calculated using the Scherrer equation. The FT-IR analysis was performed using Bruker Tensor II instrument. Standard KBr was used for the background of samples. The TEM images of the samples were obtained using a JEOL 2010 electron microscope. The XPS spectra were recorded using a Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi Spectrometer with Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV). The X-ray source operated at 15 kV and 15 mA. The binding energy was corrected using C1s signal. The H2-TPR and CO2-TPD analyses were carried out using a Quantachrome CHEMBET 3000 instrument equipped with thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Typically, 50 mg of catalyst was loaded in a quartz reactor and treated the sample at 150 °C under Ar gas flow, then H2-TPR test was carried out by using 5 % H2+95 % Ar as reductant at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min. The response from the TCD was recorded to obtain the H2-TPR pattern. For CO2-TPD, the samples were pretreated at 150 °C for 1 h and cooled down to 30 °C in Ar gas flow. Then, the sample was saturated with CO2 for 30 min and then finally, the temperature of the sample increased to 700 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. The CO2-TPD pattern was obtained by recording the TCD response. The textural properties such as BET surface area, pore volume and pore diameter of the samples were determined from the results of N2 physisorption experiments conducted at −196 °C using a Quantachrome NOVA4000 instrument. 2.5 CO2 methanation over synthesized NiSil catalysts The catalytic CO2 methanation activity of the synthesized catalysts was evaluated using a fixed bed micro reactor under atmospheric pressure. The activity tests were carried out in a quartz tube by placing 100 mg of calcined catalyst sample between the two quartz wool layers. The activation step was conducted by treating the catalyst with H2 before starting the CO2 methanation by flowing the 25 mLmin−1 of H2 gas at 600 °C for 2 h, then the reactant gases (CO2:H2 = 1:4) were introduced into the reactor with a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 18,000 mLg−1h−1. An Agilent gas chromatograph (GC-7890B) equipped with mass and thermal conductivity detectors was used to analyze the gaseous reactants and products produced by the reaction. The following formulas were used to calculate the percentage CO2 conversion (X CO2), percentage CH4 selectivity (S CH4), and CH4 yield (Y CH4). (1) X CO2 = (CO2 inlet moles-CO2 outlet moles)/CO2 inlet moles × 100 (2) SCH4 = CH4 moles outlet/(CO2 inlet moles-CO2 outlet moles) × 100 (3) YCH4 = X CO2 X SCH4 3 Results and discussion The powder XRD analysis was used to investigate the structure and phase purity of the synthesized bare and Zn decorated nickel silicate nanotubes samples. The calcined catalysts exhibited broad reflections at 11.0°, 19.4°, 28.6°, 35.8° and 60.7° corresponding to the characteristic of 2:1 nickel silicate compound with chemical formula of Ni3Si4O12H2 [JCPDS#22–0711]. After Zn decoration, the NiSil samples did not exhibit any sharp reflections due to presence of additional crystalline phases such as Ni, NiO or ZnO as shown in Fig. 1 (A). This observation indicates that the NiSil nanotubes crystal structure is intact, and the Zn species are dispersed well on the NiSil surface, or it is possible that the crystallite size of the formed Zn or ZnO species is under detection limit. However, it is interesting to note that the position of the reflection corresponding to (002) plane at 2θ = 10.7° is shifted to lower 2θ angles [Fig. 1(B)], which revealing the increase in unit cell volume due to inclusion of Zn species. The TEM analysis was performed to investigate the location of Zn species in Zn decorated NiSil samples (Fig. 2 ). The TEM image of bare NiSil sample clearly shows the presence of bundles of nanotubes with multiwalled structure. The average length of the nanotubes is around 12 nm, while the diameter is around 0.5 nm. The d-spacing of 0.45 nm between the (200) planes suggesting that the nanotubes are scrolled in the (100) direction as previously reported in the literature [21]. The observed results indicate that the solvothermal synthesis yielded with highly anisotropic nickel silicate nanotubes. This feature can be possible because of the nanotubular phyllosilicate crystal growth in addition to conventional crystal growth during the solvothermal process. The TEM images of Zn decorated NiSil samples exhibited presence of nanotubes with black material dispersed on the nanotubes surface, which is different from the bare NiSil sample as shown in Fig. 2. The samples still maintained the NiSil nanotube structure with a narrow size distribution after Zn decoration. In the magnified TEM image of 0.5Zn-NiSil and 1.0Zn-NiSil samples shows presence of agglomerated NiSil nanotubes with slightly low length and diameter as 10 nm 0.4 nm respectively. The change in the length and diameter during the Zn decoration is probably due to sonication treatment, however, presence of large size Zn or Zn oxide nanomaterials were not observed in Zn decorated NiSil samples indicating the high dispersion Zn species on the surface of NiSil. The FT-IR spectroscopy results were obtained to investigate the functional groups and the changes or modification that occurred after Zn deposition. Fig. 3 . illustrates the FT-IR spectra of bare and Zn deposited nickel silicate nanotubes samples. The FT-IR spectrum of the bare NiSil sample shows a major absorption peak at 1035 cm−1 which could be attributed to the presence of Si-O-Ni functional groups. The absorption peak appearing at 685 cm−1 could be attributed to the lattice vibration of Ni-O bonds in the nickel silicate structure [36]. The broad peak at 3450 cm−1 and sharp peak at 1640 cm−1 refer to the appearance of hydroxyl groups in the nickel silicate structure [37]. The minor intense band at 2920 cm−1 could be assigned to overtone in plane bending vibration of H-О-H bonds [38]. In addition, the IR absorption peak showed at 1375 cm−1 could be assigned to COO− groups presented on the nickel silicate surface. After deposition of Zn, the samples exhibited few changes in their FT-IR spectra as the peak position of the major absorption peak at 1035 cm−1 is shifted to 1015 cm−1, which is probably due to the increase of Si-O-Ni bond length. The interaction among the Si, Ni and Zn species could be the reason for the increase of Si-O-Ni bond length. In contrast, the intensity of peaks at 1375 cm−1 and 2920 cm−1 decreased with increase of Zn loading revealing that Zn species are interacted with HO-H and COO− groups of nickel silicate surface. It is also interesting to note that the intensity absorption peak at 685 cm−1 enhances with Zn loading which may be result of the Zn and Ni-O bonds interaction. The presented FT-IR spectra shows a clear indication that Zn species are presented on the surface of nickel silicate nanotubes. The DRUV-vis spectra for the synthesized samples were obtained to investigate some structural features of the samples (Fig. 4 ). The UV–vis spectrum of bare NiSil samples shows a major absorption peak centered at 250 nm, which is attributed to the ligand to metal charge transfer (LMCT) transition between O (2p) and Ni (3d). [39]. The weak absorbance peak appeared around 425 nm can be attributed to the low amount intra 3d transition of Ni2+ species [40]. The Zn deposited NiSil samples showed similar UV–vis spectra however the major absorption peak shifted to 255 nm, and it is known that change in absorbance to a longer wavelength could be due to presence of a substituent on a chromophore that leads to a red shift. It is also clear that the intensity of the broad absorption peak centered at 425 nm increased with increase of Zn loading. These observations indicate that deposition of Zn species on the NiSil surface, the absorbance intensity significantly increases compared to bare NiSil and suggest an improved light absorption in case of Zn deposited NiSil samples. The textural properties of synthesized bare and ZnO deposited NiSil samples were investigated using N2 physisorption analysis. It is clear from Fig. 5 that all the samples exhibited type V isotherms, which is a characteristic for mesoporous materials as per IUPAC classification [41]. The presence of H2 Type hysteresis loops in all the isotherms reveals that the materials possessed with disordered bottleneck shaped pores. It is interesting to note that deposition of ZnO has no effect on the isotherm pattern or the hysteresis loop, which may be due to the lower ZnO loading, however the loop size for the ZnO deposited samples gets smaller with increasing the ZnO loading possibly due to deposition of Zn species on the pore walls. The pore size distribution patterns of the samples exhibited a minor peak at 14 Å and major peak at around 20 Å, with average size around 19 Å. The big pore size is mainly due to presence of the open NiSil nanotubes in the catalysts. Table 1 shows the BET surface area, pore volume and pore radius of the samples and it is clear that the surface area and pore volume of ZnO contained samples increased with increasing of ZnO loading. The XPS spectral analysis provides information about the elements on the surface of the sample by giving the relation between the number of detected electrons and binding energy. The deconvoluted Ni2p, Si2p, O1s and Zn2p XPS spectra for bare and ZnO deposited NiSil samples are shown in Fig. 6 . The bare NiSil sample exhibited peaks at 874.2 eV and 855.2 eV, which could be attributed to Ni2p1/2 and Ni2p3/2 respectively for Ni2+ species in the nickel silicate framework, and the peaks appeared at 880.2 eV and 867.1 eV could be assigned to the satellite peaks of Ni2p1/2 and Ni2p3/2 , respectively [25,42]. The appearance of the two different sets of Ni2p peaks for all the ZnO deposited NiSil samples is clearly observed. As shown in figure, Ni2p3/2 peak is split in to two peaks: the first peak at 855.2 eV is attributed to Ni2+ species present in the nickel silicate and the second peak at 859.6 eV is assigned to Ni2+ species interacted with Zn species presented in the supported nanotube samples [43]. This observation indicates the existence of different types of Ni2+ species is observed in all the ZnO deposited NiSil samples. The Si2p XPS spectrum of NiSil sample exhibited a major peak at 103.0 eV, which indicates the presence of Si4+ species in the NiSil sample [44]. The observed Si2p binding energy, 103.0 eV is lower than SiO2 (103.8 eV) and close to that of NiSiO3 (103.3 eV). The XPS data also confirms that nickel silicate nanotubes were obtained under adapted solvothermal conditions. The broadness of the Si2p peak reveals the existence of Si-O-Si and Si-OH bonds in the synthesized NiSil samples. It is interesting to note that the Si2p spectra of ZnO deposited samples clearly showed presence of two distinct peaks at 103.1 eV and 104.7 eV, which could be due to Si-O-Si and Si-O-Zn species respectively. The O1s spectrum of NiSil sample showed a broad peak observed at 532.1 eV indicates O2− species in Si-O-Si species[44]. Deconvolution of O1s spectra of ZnO deposited revealed the existence of three different peaks for the oxygen atoms. The peak at binding energy of 532.2 eV is assigned to the oxygen atom in Si-O-Si whereas the second peak at 533.7 eV is ascribed to the oxygen atom in Si-OH species. The third peak at binding energy of 535.0 eV could be attributed to the Si-O-Zn interactive species. The Zn2p XPS spectra of 0.25Zn-NiSil and 0.5Zn-NiSil samples showed Zn2p peaks at 1022.5 and 1045.5 eV, which are attributed to Zn2+, while the other two peaks at 1019.3 eV and 1042.2 eV belong to Zn-O-Si interactive species [32,45]. However, the 1.0Zn-NiSil sample exhibited peaks only due to surface Zn2+ species, which indicates the formation of surface ZnO species due to increase of ZnO loading on the NiSil surface. It is clear that 0.25Zn-NiSil sample showed presence of more surface Zn-O-Si interactive species as the intensity of the peaks corresponding to interactive species is higher than Zn2+ species. The H2-TPR analysis was performed to examine the reduction behavior of bare and the Zn deposited NiSil catalysts (Fig. 7 ). The TPR patterns would provide an insight into the metal-support interactions in Zn-NiSil catalysts. The bulk NiSil sample exhibited a major intense reduction peak around 470 °C with a minor shoulder peak centered at 408 °C and these peaks could be due to reduction of nickel silicate species [46]. The presence of shoulder peak could be due to the existence of nickel silicate nanotubes with two different sizes. It is well known that the big size particles tend to be reduced slower compared to small particles, because of their relatively smaller surface area exposed to H2 gas. The previous literature reports [47,48] clearly indicated that bulk NiO crystallites exhibit reduction peaks below 400 °C. Zhao et al. [49] reported the TPR peak appeared around 674 °C is due to the reduction of nickel silicate species in NiO/SiO2 catalysts. However, the nickel silicate species prepared in the present work is different from the nickel silicate species found in NiO/SiO2 catalysts. The H2-TPR pattern of bulk NiSil sample indicates that the synthesized Ni3Si4O12H2 species are easily reducible compared to the nickel silicates species generated in the NiO/SiO2 catalysts. The H2-TPR patterns of the 0.25Zn-NiSil and 0.5Zn-NiSil samples showed an additional reduction peak at 535 °C due to the enhanced interaction between Zn species and nickel silicate species. Further increase of Zn loading led to changes in the H2-TPR pattern as the 1.0Zn-NiSil sample showed additional peak at 245 °C (low temperature) mainly due to reduction of isolated ZnO species. The integral intensities of the peaks after deconvoluting H2-TPR patterns indicate that 0.25Zn-NiSil sample possessed high number of Zn-NiSil interactive species compared to other samples. In the sample with low Zn concentration, Zn is strongly interacted with NiSil support, which required high temperature to reduce as observed in the TPR pattern. Loading of 1.0 wt.%Zn led to agglomeration of NiSil nanotubes which needs long time and high temperature. The low Zn concentration responsible for the formation of the highly dispersed NiSil nanotubes and Zn oxide species which were quickly reduced compared to high loading samples. The CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD experiments were performed to determine the surface basicity and acidity of the synthesized catalysts. The CO2-TPD technique also measures the chemical CO2 adsorption ability of catalysts. It is well known that the basic sites on the catalyst surface are important for CO2 adsorption and activation, which are suitable for CO2 methanation. Fig. 8 (A) shows CO2-TPD patterns of the calcined samples and it is clear that the bulk NiSil sample exhibits only one major desorption peak at high temperature (750 °C) indicates that it possesses only strong basic sites. It is interesting to note that loading of Zn resulted in appearance of additional CO2 desorption peak at 100 °C with different intensities revealing that weak basic sites are generated due to Zn deposition on the surface of NiSil. It is also clear that the major desorption peak shifted to lower temperature after Zn loading (0.25Zn-NiSil-650 °C, 0.5Zn-NiSil-680 °C and 1.0Zn-NiSil-690 °C). The CO2-TPD results indicating the presence of both weak and strong basic sites were presented in NiSil catalysts with Zn species. Interestingly, the intensity of desorption peaks increased after 0.25 wt.% Zn loading and then decreased for 0.5 wt.% and 1.0 wt.% catalysts. Previous literature reports [50,51] revealed that nickel silicate catalyst exhibits mostly weak basic sites along with some of the medium basic sites, however the synthesized NiSil samples exhibited mostly strong basic sites probably due to different structure, morphology and elemental (Ni, Si and Zn) composition. Among the synthesized catalysts, the 0.25Zn-NiSil catalyst showed high number of weak and strong basic sites. The NH3-TPD patterns normally classified as low, medium, and high temperature regions. The low temperature desorption peak reveals the presence of weak acid sites, whereas the high temperature desorption peak represents to strong acidic sites [51]. It is clear from the Fig. 8(B) that the bare and Zn deposited NiSil samples exhibited broad desorption peak at around 190 °C with different peak intensities. In NiSil structures, presence of Si-OH functional groups on the NiSil surface provides weak Brønsted acid sites, while the coordinatively unsaturated Ni species responsible for Lewis acidity [50]. The decrease of NH3 desorption peak intensity with the increase of Zn loading from 0.25 to 1.0 wt.%. Therefore, the surface of Zn loaded NiSil catalysts contains not only a large number of strong basic sites but also some weakly acid sites. Among the Zn loaded NiSil samples 0.25Zn-NiSil sample exhibited high number of basic and acidic sites, which could play a role in the CO2 adsorption and methanation. The synthesized bare and Zn deposited NiSil nanomaterials were utilized as catalysts for CO2 methanation, and the obtained are shown in Fig. 9 (A-D). The catalytic performance results reveal that the Zn deposited NiSil catalysts exhibit better catalytic performance compared to bare NiSil nanotube catalyst, specifically the 0.25Zn-NiSil catalyst with 0.25 wt.% Zn loading. It is clear from Fig. 9(A) that the bare NiSil catalyst offered 30 % at 250 °C, while the 0.25Zn-NiSil exhibited CO2 conversion of 43 % under same reaction conditions. A similar trend in CO2 conversions was observed at other investigated reaction temperatures. The 0.25Zn-NiSil catalyst offered better catalytic performance at different reaction temperatures, from 250 to 450 °C. The high CO2 conversion (95 %) was observed in case of 0.25Zn-NiSil catalyst at 400 °C. Further increase of reaction temperature to 450 °C has not shown any considerable change in CO2 conversion. The increase of Zn loading over the NiSil surface resulted in decrease of catalytic performance, which reveals role of Zn on the CO2 methanation activity of the NiSil catalysts. The bare and Zn deposited NiSil catalysts exhibited high methane selectivity (89–99 %) at different reaction temperatures. Carbon monoxide (CO) is the only another product observed during the analysis of the product streams at different reaction temperatures over bare and Zn deposited NiSil catalysts. The 0.25Zn-NiSil catalyst showed highest methane selectivity (99 %) with high CO2 conversion at low reaction temperatures 250–350 °C indicating that the deposition of an optimum loading of Zn could enhance the efficacy of NiSil catalysts in CO2 methanation performance. In addition, to investigate the stability of NiSil and 0.25Zn-NiSil catalysts, the time on stream analysis was performed at 400 °C by maintaining the GHSV of 18,000 mLg−1h−1. It is beneficial to obtain the activity of NiSil catalyst with lower Zn content (less than 0.25 wt.%) because the activity is decreasing with increase of Zn loading. A NiSil sample with 0.1 wt.% Zn was prepared and tested for the CO2 methanation under the same reaction conditions and the obtained results showed that the activity is lower (91 % CO2 conversion and 94 % CH4 selectivity) compared to the catalyst containing 0.25 wt.% Zn. Therefore, 0.25 wt.% of Zn is the optimum loading for NiSil catalyst. As shown in Fig. 9(D), the two catalysts exhibited excellent stability even after 48 h of reaction, and the CH4 yields were found to be 89 and 94 %, respectively. There is a slight decrease from 89 % to 84 % in the case of NiSil catalyst after 48 h. The CH4 yields obtained for NiSil catalysts with different Zn loadings revealed that the methanation activity of the catalyst decreased with increase of Zn content and the catalytic activity of CO2 methanation is highest when Zn loading is 0.25 wt.%. With an increase of Zn amount above 0.25 wt.%, the CH4 yields were gradually decreased. In addition, the CO2 conversion rates were determined for all the synthesized catalysts and Zn deposited NiSil catalysts exhibited higher reaction rates. It is clear that the bare NiSil sample showed higher apparent activation energy (Ea) of 91.4 kJ/mol. while the Ea for the 0.25Zn-NiSil catalyst is around 86.2 kJ/mol (Fig. 10 ). Therefore, 0.25Zn-NiSil catalyst possessed more catalytically active sites and lower activation energy. The observations from the CO2 methanation experiments could be explained based on catalyst characterization results and literature findings. Sivaiah et al. [52] reported that the nickel phyllosilicates could be partially reduced by H2 at temperatures at above 500 °C. In another report, Wang et al. observed that reduction of Ni/ZnO catalysts at higher temperature resulted the enhanced CO2 methanation performance due to strong interaction between Ni and ZnO [53]. The XPS and H2-TPR results clearly revealed the presence of more surface Zn-NiSil interactive species in case of 0.25Zn-NiSil catalyst compared to other Zn deposited NiSil catalysts. The interaction between Zn and NiSil not only leads to an improved dispersion of active species but can also cause encapsulation of the active sites. It was also reported that other factors such as addition of promoters could influence the CO2 methanation reaction mechanism. Addition of alkaline earth metals such as Mg and Ca to Ni-Al2O3 catalyst resulted in generation of carbonate species due to the increased basicity, while addition of Sr and Ba enhanced the production of CO and HCO radicals. It is a known fact that CO2 is an acidic molecule and adsorbs on basic sites, therefore tuning the catalyst basicity is an important step to control the CO2 adsorption capacity. It was also observed that a greater number of basic sites could enhance the apparent catalytic CO2 methanation activity [54]. Muyoyama et al. [55] used different supports such as Y2O3, Sm2O3, ZrO2, CeO2, Al2O3, and La2O3 to deposit the Ni species and investigated the influence of support basicity and CO2 methanation. The authors concluded that Ni deposited Y2O3 showed the high activity due to the largest amount of CO2 desorbed at 400 °C during the CO2 temperature desorption measurements. In the present study, deposition of Zn on the surface of NiSil clearly resulted in increase of CO2 desorption amount and compared with other catalysts, the 0.25Zn-NiSil sample showed more CO2 desorption with number of strong basic sites. Deposition of different amounts of Zn promoter has no effect on the CO2 methanation reaction pathway, as the same products (CH4 and CO) were observed in case of both bare and Zn deposited NiSil catalysts. It appears that CO2 adsorbed on surface of the synthesized nickel silicate nanotubes and the adsorbed CO2 was transformed into the CH4 as shown in Scheme 2 [32]. Different researchers proposed different CO2 methanation pathways based experimental and computational investigations [56], however there are only two widely accepted pathways for CO2 conversion into methane. The first one is the HCO pathway where HCO radical species are the intermediate products and the second one is the CO pathway, where generation of CO radical species and their hydrogenation to CH4 by dissociated hydrogen atoms on the active metal particles. Previously, Bukhari et al. [57] reported the occurrence of dissociation of CO2 into CO and O species as well as H2 dissociation into atomic hydrogen species over Ni supported fibrous silicate (SBA-15) catalysts. In another report, Cerdá-Moreno et al. [58] used operando DRIFTS technique to study the CO2 methanation reaction mechanism over Ni supported magnesium silicate catalyst and observed the formation of linearly and bridged bonded CO as intermediates. A similar reaction mechanism could be expected to occur in the case of Zn deposited nickel silicate nanotube catalysts. 4 Conclusions The nickel silicate (NiSil) nanotubes sample was prepared by adapting simple solvothermal synthesis method and the Zn species were deposited by chemical reduction technique using sonication. The CO2 methanation activity results demonstrated that the 0.25Zn-NiSil catalyst exhibited significantly high CO2 methanation activity among synthesized catalysts. The 0.25Zn-NiSil sample achieved 90 % CO2 conversion and 98% CH4 selectivity at 300 °C, which is higher than Ni and SiO2 contained catalysts. In addition, characterization of synthesized Zn deposited NiSil samples was performed by using different techniques and the results demonstrated that the Zn deposited nickel silicate nanotubes exhibit a strong Zn-NiSil interaction. The addition of 0.25 wt.% Zn resulted in reducibility and basicity of the Zn deposited NiSil catalyst. The improved stability of the Zn deposited NiSil catalysts for CO2 methanation is due to the enhanced interaction between Zn and NiSil support. The present research reveals the promising future of metal-silicate nanomaterials for CO2 utilization to produce valuable chemicals. The cost-effective catalysts could draw significant attention for large scale implementation in the industrial sector. The Zn deposition resulted in obtaining high CH4 yields over the synthesized catalysts at low reaction temperature, which encourages researchers to investigate the promotion of multi-metals over the metal silicate support. coredata.dc:description: Global energy demand has connected with the environment and economic concern, and this led to an intensive focus toward carbon dioxide (CO2) capture and conversion to valuable products. Chemical conversion of CO2 via hydrogenation to methane is the interesting process that meets these growing needs. The necessity of development of a low price, and active sustainable catalyst resulted in focus on utilization of Ni and SiO2 containing catalysts for CO2 to methane at mild reaction temperature. In this contribution, nickel silicate (NiSil) nanotubes sample was prepared by solvothermal process and different loadings (0.25 to 1.0 wt.%) of Zn nanoparticles were chemically deposited on the surface of NiSil nanotubes. The 0.25Zn-NiSil catalyst exhibited significant high performance with CO2 conversion greater than 90 % at 300 °C with high good stability (for 48 h). The synthesized samples were analyzed using XRD, FT-IR, TEM, DRUV–vis XPS, H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, NH3-TPD and N2 physisorption techniques. The results indicate that the synthesized nickel silicate nanotubes possess high specific surface area and pore volume and deposition of Zn loading on NiSil surface increases reducibility and number of basic sites due to interaction between Zn-NiSil. Highly dispersed Zn-NiSil species on the surface 0.25Zn-NiSil sample are the key factors for high catalytic activity in CO2 methanation.
coredata.dc:title: Zn deposited nickel silicate nanotubes as efficient CO2 methanation catalysts
